title: Erigeron compositus
text:
Erigeron compositus is an <a href="Arctic%20tundra">Arctic</a> and <a href="Alpine%20tundra">alpine</a> species of <a href="Erigeron">fleabane</a> in the <a href="Asteraceae">daisy family</a>. Common names include dwarf mountain fleabane, cutleaf daisy, and trifid mountain fleabane.
"Erigeron compositus" has been found in the <a href="Russian%20Far%20East">Russian Far East</a> (<a href="Wrangel%20Island">Wrangel Island</a> and <a href="Chukotka%20Autonomous%20Okrug">Chukotka</a>), <a href="Alaska">Alaska</a>, <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a>, much of <a href="Canada">Canada</a> (all three <a href="Canadian%20Arctic%20Lands">Arctic</a> territories plus <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>, all three <a href="Prairie%20Provinces">Prairie Provinces</a>, <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>, <a href="Newfoundland">Newfoundland</a>, and <a href="Nova%20Scotia">Nova Scotia</a>), and the <a href="Western%20United%20States">Western United States</a> (from the <a href="Pacific%20Coast">Pacific Coast</a> as far east as the <a href="Dakotas">Dakotas</a>, <a href="Colorado">Colorado</a>, and <a href="New%20Mexico">New Mexico</a>).
"Erigeron compositus" is <a href="Perennial%20plant">perennial</a> herb rarely more than tall, with a thick growth of basal leaves, the tips of which are divided. The plant produces a <a href="taproot">taproot</a> and spreads by means of horizontal underground <a href="rhizome">rhizome</a>s. There is generally only one <a href="flower%20head">flower head</a> per stem, each head with 20–60 white, pink or blue <a href="ray%20florets">ray florets</a>; these are sometimes small and easily mistaken for <a href="disc%20floret">disc floret</a>s. Genuine disc florets are yellow and in the center of the head.
